Title: The 50 Best Christmas Movies, from ‚ÄòEyes Wide Shut‚Äô and ‚ÄòCarol‚Äô to ‚ÄòBatman Returns‚Äô and ‚ÄòChristmas Vacation‚Äô
URL: https://www.indiewire.com/gallery/christmas-movies-best-holiday-films/
Time Published: 2025-12-08T16:00:18Z
Full Content:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy. We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply. In the spirit of the magic of the season (and in hopes of providing some warm respite from the usual end-of-the-year best-of deluge of stories and their attendant doldrums), IndieWire is proud to present our first-ever Holiday Week. [Editor‚Äôs note: This list was originally published in December 2022. It has since been updated with new entries.] Rockin‚Äô around the Christmas tree at the Christmas movie stop! That‚Äôs right: You‚Äôve reached the North Pole of movie recommendations, where our toymakers (read: film critics) have been hard at work sifting through titles all year long. It‚Äôs easy to think of holiday movies as the one area of cinema audiences have permission to practically forget about the rest of the year. With a limited window between Thanksgiving and Christmas, most film lovers can only make time for a handful of seasonally appropriate screenings before New Year‚Äôs snaps our attention back to awards season and the big Best Picture contenders. Plus, with new yuletide offerings hitting theaters and streaming platforms in a steady flurry throughout December, there‚Äôs only so much time to enjoy Christmas classics while staying current on new holiday fare. Selection is made even more complex when you get into the Christmas genre‚Äôs inexplicable tendency toward gatekeeping. It‚Äôs a frustrating reality of the movie machine that some titles, for no real discernible reason, get saddled with debates that have relatively little to do with their stories. Such is the case with John McTiernan‚Äôs ‚ÄúDie Hard‚Äù: the 1988 action-packed crowdpleaser starring Bruce Willis that‚Äôs become synonymous with the contentious classification of so-called ‚ÄúChristmas movies‚Äù and the separately defined ‚Äúmovies set at Christmas.‚Äù In curating this list, we‚Äôve disregarded that delineation, allowing Stanley Kubrick‚Äôs psychosexual thriller ‚ÄúEyes Wide Shut‚Äù and Bob Clark‚Äôs slasher ‚ÄúBlack Christmas‚Äù their rightful spots alongside traditional TV specials, from ‚ÄúA Charlie Brown Christmas‚Äù to ‚ÄúRudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer.‚Äù The best Christmas movies, as defined here, make up a collection of films celebrating and/or challenging the holiday while using its motifs and themes to explore the light and dark sides of the human spirit. Selections have been ranked with both Christmas relevance and overall film quality in mind. Check out IndieWire‚Äôs guide to the best Thanksgiving movies. With editorial contributions by David Ehrlich, Jim Hemphill, Sarah Shachat, and Christian Zilko. You‚Äôd be hard-pressed to find a Disney fan willing to argue ‚ÄúBeauty and the Beast: The Enchanted Christmas‚Äù is ‚Äúbetter‚Äù than the original. But director Andy Knight‚Äôs straight-to-VHS release from 1997 ‚Äî a ‚Äúmidquel‚Äù imagining Belle and the Beast‚Äôs first Christmas, from before Gaston leads that angry mob to their castle in the first film ‚Äî is ridiculously magical. The story sees none other than Tim Curry give voice to the formidable Forte. A grumpy composer turned into an evil pipe organ by the witch‚Äôs curse, the hidden gem Disney villain doesn‚Äôt want the spell broken because he likes his new life. The late Paul Reubens voices Forte‚Äôs right-hand, Fife, a trembling piccolo willing to do anything for the solo his conductor has promised him if the Beast doesn‚Äôt become human. ‚ÄúEnchanted Christmas‚Äù makes heavy use of early CGI (Forte himself is entirely digital) and it lacks much of the hand-drawn charm that made the earlier masterpiece. But with Bernadette Peters adding even more holiday cheer ‚Äî she‚Äôs a tree angel and love interest for Lumiere (Jerry Orbach, again) ‚Äî this is the seed that planted the forest of holiday spin-offs Disney devotees continue to enjoy each year. ‚ÄîAF Netflix has attempted more than its fair share of Christmas movies, including Best Animated Feature nominee ‚ÄúKlaus‚Äù in 2019. But ‚ÄúJingle Jangle: A Christmas Journey‚Äù stands out from the streaming service‚Äôs crowd ‚Äî offering everything from a Dolly Parton musical to Kurt Russell as Santa ‚Äî with writer/director David Talbert‚Äôs delightfully overstuffed celebration of holiday excess. A blistering race through Christmas spectacle, musical bangers, top-notch acting, and maybe (read: definitely) one too many steampunk-inspired visual effects, ‚ÄúJingle Jangle‚Äù makes for a snow globe-like display akin to a modern spin on the chorus line musical extravaganzas of yesteryear. Originally envisioned as a stage production, the 2020 straight-to-streaming film follows Forest Whittaker‚Äôs inventor character as he bonds with his brilliant granddaughter, portrayed by Madalen Mills. Together, they pull off a harrowing rescue mission, unravel a dastardly plot, and find new hope in the holiday spirit. ‚ÄîAF For the only tie on this list, we offer up two adaptations of Dr. Seuss‚Äô ‚ÄúHow the Grinch Stole Christmas‚Äù (knowing full well there are at least two other features you could consider that don‚Äôt make the cut). The 1957 children‚Äôs story was adapted first by ‚ÄúLooney Tunes‚Äù artist Chuck Jones and his longtime collaborator Ben Washam in a brilliantly crafted animated special, which aired on CBS in December 1966. This version boasts Boris Karloff as the voice of the Grinch: a performance that would shape the humbug-turned-unlikely hero for decades to come. Channelling Karloff‚Äôs rendering and the curling physicality of Jones and Washam‚Äôs illustrative design, Jim Carrey totally embodies the fabled mean one in Ron Howard‚Äôs live-action outing from 2000. The aughts favorite is perhaps most celebrated for its quotable lines (‚ÄúAm I just eating because I‚Äôm bored?‚Äù) but is infamous for its intense prosthetics and costuming, which Carrey reportedly despised. Still, it earned three Oscar nominations and won for Best Makeup. ‚ÄîAF On par with ‚ÄúThe Music Box‚Äù and ‚ÄúWay Out West‚Äù as a matter of family fun, this Laurel and Hardy musical from 1934 adapts parts of Victor Herbert‚Äôs 1903 stage production for a fantastic fairytale adventure revolving around a home mortgage dispute (yes, really). The film‚Äôs slap-happy concoction of over-the-top physicality, show-stopping musical numbers, and recognizable storybook characters ‚Äì including the big man himself, Santa ‚Äî makes this comedy of errors in Toyland, also known as ‚ÄúMarch of the Wooden Soldiers,‚Äù the best version to date. There have been multiple ‚ÄúBabes in Toyland‚Äù movies made for TV, as well as Disney‚Äôs 1961 theatrical feature and 1997‚Äôs animated take from MGM. ‚ÄîAF Considering the prevalence of his origin story, it‚Äôs a wonder Rudolph hasn‚Äôt enjoyed a more successful run in film. Sure, Santa‚Äôs ninth reindeer appears in some form or another for most of the big man‚Äôs movies; even ‚ÄúThe Nightmare Before Christmas‚Äù gives Jack‚Äôs ghost dog Zero an excuse to cosplay as his yuletide counterpart. But as far as standalone Rudolph outings go, nothing has surpassed the 1964 stop-motion TV special (first aired on NBC) and the instantly recognizable franchise it would inspire. ‚ÄúRudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer‚Äù joyfully expands on its namesake poem (and song!) with a story introducing new characters, from love interest Clarice to the Abominable Snow Monster. That tradition would continue in prequel and sequel films, most notably with the iconic Heat Miser in 1974‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Year Without Santa Claus.‚Äù Still, this is one instance where, if you only have time to enjoy a single film, the original can‚Äôt be beat for its hand-crafted care and inherent nostalgia. ‚ÄîAF No, don‚Äôt scoff! Yes, ‚ÄúLast Christmas‚Äù is a shaggy, odd thing of a film, and yes, the end twist is infamously ridiculous (and also pretty easy to see coming). But Paul Feig‚Äôs underrated London Christmas fantasy is also a moving portrayal of self-improvement and growth, with a genuinely wonderful turn from Emilia Clarke as an aimless and surly menial shop worker at its center. Struggling after a health emergency and carrying strained relationships with pretty much everyone in her life, Clarke‚Äôs Kate gets a new lease on life when she meets and bonds with Henry Golding‚Äôs charming Tom. But ‚ÄúLast Christmas‚Äù actually works best when it isn‚Äôt a romance: there‚Äôs some real edge to Clarke‚Äôs portrayal of Kate and her self-destructive attitude that gives the film some unexpected grit, and the screenplay manages to make her eventual redemption feel genuinely earned. Plus, they deliver what you want from a movie with this title, with a stirring closing performance of Wham‚Äôs ‚ÄúLast Christmas‚Äù that‚Äôs simply magical. ‚ÄîWC A simple but nourishing ode to the power of good deeds, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre No Angels‚Äù sees famous hardboiled cynic Humphrey Bogart take a stab at spreading cheer and whimsy. Michael Curtiz‚Äôs film sees the ‚ÄúCasablanca‚Äù leading man play Joseph, a prisoner who jail breaks himself from Devil‚Äôs Island along with two buddies (Peter Ustinov and Aldo Ray), taking refuge in a local shop. Although they plan to rob the place blind and leave, a Christmas dinner with the kindhearted, struggling family makes them reconsider, as they dedicate themselves to helping their hosts instead. A little weird and wild in its plotting (a venomous snake comes into play), ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre No Angels‚Äù nonetheless is a sweet and simple tale of Christmas redemption, that also has a wee dash of effortless Bogart suave. ‚ÄîWC This horror film about a kid traumatized on Christmas who grows up to go on a killing spree while dressed as Santa sparked national outrage when it was released in 1984, angering parents and critics with both its content and its lurid marketing materials. (Those of us who grew up in the era will never forget the poster with Santa coming out of the chimney with an ax.) As is so often the case, the movie itself got lost in the controversy ‚Äî which is a shame, because it‚Äôs a stone cold slasher masterpiece. Filled with genuine wit and gleeful irony courtesy of screenwriter Michael Hickey, it‚Äôs very funny and earns its shocks; director Charles Sellier was a TV producer with hundreds of hours of on-set experience, and his proficient craftsmanship makes this a grim, hilarious Christmas classic. ‚ÄîJH One year before ‚ÄúDie Hard,‚Äù writer Shane Black and director Richard Donner brought us the first truly great Christmas action movie of the 80s and made the definitive buddy cop flick in the process. From the opening strains of ‚ÄúJingle Bell Rock‚Äù on the soundtrack and the expertly choreographed shoot-out in a Christmas tree lot to the overall sense of bittersweet holiday melancholy that permeates the proceedings, this is pure Christmas cinema nirvana. Shane Black would return to the holidays many times in many great films (‚ÄúThe Long Kiss Goodnight,‚Äù ‚ÄúKiss Kiss Bang Bang,‚Äù ‚ÄúPlay Dirty‚Äù), but this is the gold standard. ‚ÄîJH It‚Äôs been overshadowed in recent years by Greta Gerwig‚Äôs genuinely revelatory adaptation, but the 1994 ‚ÄúLittle Women‚Äù film by Gillian Armstrong has its charms and its pleasures, from a brilliant performance as Jo by a spirited Winona Ryder, an early killer role from Kirsten Dunst as a young Amy, and Christian Bale giving a defining heartthrob turn as a particularly charming Laurie. And like all adaptations of Louisa May Alcott‚Äôs beloved novel, the 1994 ‚ÄúLittle Women‚Äù is a perfect movie to watch during the holidays, between the comforting golden hue with which it renders its rural Massachusetts setting and the bright, decadent costumes on display. The Christmas scenes are more tearjerking than they are joyous, though. ‚ÄîWC Shane Black returns to the subgenre he invented in ‚ÄúLethal Weapon‚Äù with another terrific Christmas action script, this one about an amnesiac teacher (Geena Davis) who learns she was a ruthless assassin in a past life. Director Renny Harlin tears into Black‚Äôs script like a Doberman into a prime rib, milking every last set piece for maximum impact ‚Äî the shoot-outs, car chases, and knife fights are spectacularly entertaining and get a lot of added flavor out of the Christmastime setting. Holiday purists might be put off by the Christmas cheer existing alongside violent torture scenes and Geena Davis spouting dialogue like, ‚ÄúSuck my dick,‚Äù but if cynical Christmas movies are your thing, this one is tough to beat. ‚ÄîJH There are many horrible Christmas movies Netflix has inflicted upon the world, from ‚ÄúThe Christmas Prince‚Äù to ‚ÄúHot Frosty.‚Äù Easily the best, and a genuine treat to treasure, is Sergio Pablos‚Äô wonderful animated confection ‚ÄúKlaus.‚Äù An origin story of sorts for Santa, in which he‚Äôs a reclusive toymaker in a distant Northern town befriended and aided by a lazy postal worker, ‚ÄúKlaus‚Äù could easily verge on the silly: do we really need a prequel to the Santa mythos? But the film just works, with a sweet message preaching the importance of generosity and the perfect mix of humor and heart. And the film also looks gorgeous, using detailed, gorgeously lit 2D animation to bring its winter wonderland to life. ‚ÄîWC The holidays can provide a lovely opportunity to spend quality time with our loved ones. But, as great artists like √âric Rohmer understand so well, they can be deeply isolating weeks for single people without an obvious place to go. Random meetings with strangers can escalate into deeper connections than you might find at any other time of year ‚Äî but holidays are inherently ephemeral, and many of those newfound friendships and romances are destined to end. ‚ÄúMy Night at Maud‚Äôs‚Äù is a brilliant film about those fleeting holiday connections. Most of its characters don‚Äôt start out as strangers, per se, but they wouldn‚Äôt be nearly as close of friends at any other time of year. Cold winter nights are broken up by lengthy conversations about Pascal‚Äôs Wager, and the romance that seems to loom around the corner is thwarted by the reality that intellectual chemistry need not be indicative of any larger compatibility. The script is Rohmer‚Äôs brand of cerebral filmmaking at its absolute best, all building towards a denouement in which nothing really changes externally but everyone is left with a treasured memory. It‚Äôs not your stereotypical holiday movie, yet it hits like a snowglobe ‚Äî a perfectly preserved winter memory you can return to again and again. ‚ÄîCZ A heavily-Tarantino inspired crime comedy, Doug Liman‚Äôs ‚ÄúGo‚Äù doesn‚Äôt exactly scream Christmas cheer. But it‚Äôs set around the holidays, with the tantalizing image of a young shirtless Timothy Olyphant with a Santa hat draped on his head providing much of the Yuletide tie-in. Olyphant is just one of many, many young stars in the film, which also features people like Katie Holmes, Sarah Polley, Scott Wolf, and young Jane Krakowski and Melissa McCarthy in small roles. They all liven up the funny, ramshackle story, set across one Christmas Eve night as they try and score drugs, head on an LA trip, and try to entrap a drug dealer. Spiky dialogue and a blindingly fast pace keep the film going like a festive rush that you never wish ends. ‚ÄîWC A warm, funny tableau more than a film, ‚ÄúChristmas Eve in Miller‚Äôs Point‚Äù is a touch long for a movie so plotless. Luckily, it‚Äôs so delightful that it‚Äôs hard to actually care. Tyler Thomas Taormina‚Äôs painfully accurate portrait of Long Island families ‚Äî which will ring very close to home to anyone who‚Äôs ever grown up taking the LIRR into NYC ‚Äî features a massive ensemble playing the Balsano family, a large clan who crowd around the table of their matriarch‚Äôs home for what seems destined to be the last time. While there‚Äôs some business with the rebellious teens (including Francesca Scorsese and Elsie Fisher) sneaking away, ‚ÄúChristmas Eve in Miller‚Äôs Point‚Äù is mostly content to paint a picture of the stress, anger, and joy that comes from the holiday, and the melancholy inherent to the season. ‚ÄîWC ‚ÄúIn Bruges‚Äù is only a Christmas movie in the sense that ‚ÄúDie Hard‚Äù is a Christmas movie. But cinephiles big and small should still jump at the chance to toast the season with Martin McDonagh ‚Äî a filmmaker whose knack for delivering violent fairytales to unsuspecting audiences rivals even Santa‚Äôs grasp on global gift giving. When Irish hitmen Ray (Colin Farrell) and Ken (Brendan Gleeson) are sent to hide in the Belgian city of Bruges after a botched job, involving a priest and altar boy (yay, Catholic guilt!), they‚Äôre met with an ironically cheery setting. Shiny nostalgia can‚Äôt keep criminals off the naughty list though, and it‚Äôs not long before they‚Äôre stuck in a bloody, whipsmart game of cat-and-mouse that makes Chevy Chase and the squirrel from ‚ÄúChristmas Vacation‚Äù look like friends. It‚Äôs a dazzling testament to McDonagh‚Äôs unique ability to balance dark and light, and even as a passive backdrop, winter festivities pair remarkably well with Farrell and Gleeson‚Äôs undeniable chemistry. ‚ÄúIn Bruges‚Äù came out in 2008, years before the Oscar-winning ‚ÄúBanshees of Inisherin‚Äù reunited the actors, and Ralph Fiennes‚Äô role as a crime boss here will make you wish he was in that film, too. Watch both and you‚Äôll dream of Little Jenny pulling a flying sleigh. ‚ÄîAF Winona Ryder‚Äôs red-headed Kim dancing in the flurries of ‚Äúsnow‚Äù beneath Edward‚Äôs ice sculpture. That unforgettable image is what takes Tim Burton‚Äôs 1990 suburban fairytale from a movie that just so happens to be a Christmas to the status of bonafide holiday classic. Aesthetically wrapped in the magic of the season but with a plot too often devoid of goodwill towards men, ‚ÄúEdward Scissorhands‚Äù at once weaponizes the annual stratification that comes with ‚ÄúMy consumerist nightmare is better than your consumerist nightmare!‚Äù discourse while also allowing its characters to take refuge in the season‚Äôs pockets of joy. Featuring a memorable appearance by Vincent Price as Edward‚Äôs inventor, the film starring Johnny Depp intertwines a fairly predicated story of an outcast thrust into society with a unique character concept that elevates the rest of his sweet and sorrowful saga. ‚ÄîAF David Lowery‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Green Knight‚Äù is, canonically, a Christmas story. Sure, the 2021 film takes one of the oldest tales for the fireside in the English language and turns it into a trippy vision-quest interrogating the true nature of honor and morality with some of the lushest, most transporting, most bewildering visuals since ‚ÄúThe Fall.‚Äù That may not sound too Christmas-y. But on the other hand: Dev Patel. Tell me you don‚Äôt want to watch Dev Patel flail around in the mud while you‚Äôre digesting your Christmas meal with a straight face; you can‚Äôt. Real ones know that ‚ÄúThe Green Knight‚Äù is a fantastic Christmas movie because, like the best of them, it takes you to a place and a time wholly different from our own, and gets us to feel a little fonder, a little more grateful for our corner of this burning universe. Just be braced, if any normie relatives who happen to join you, you will probably get asked about what happens with the sash two-thirds of the way through. ‚ÄîSS After the production of ‚ÄúGhostbusters,‚Äù Bill Murray took a hiatus from filmmaking that ended (barring a cameo or two) with ‚ÄúScrooged,‚Äù which teamed him with Richard Donner for a blithe, comedic take on ‚ÄúThe Christmas Carol‚Äù story. Scrooge is now Murray‚Äôs Frank Cross, a ruthless TV executive obsessed with financial gain who gets a chance at atonement when a series of ghosts visit him on Christmas Eve to try and help him learn the error of his ways. The film‚Äôs script is a little shaky, balancing its more mean-spirited humor with the eventual sentiment somewhat poorly, but it‚Äôs all okay when Murray is such a force as the sleezeball at the center. He makes Frank‚Äôs redemption sweet despite the script issues, turning the film into a holiday staple single-handedly. Like a lot of Murray films, though, you kinda like him better when he‚Äôs being an asshole. ‚ÄîWC Man, if you think your family argues at Christmas. Arguing is, honestly, kind of the premise of ‚ÄúThe Lion In Winter.‚Äù After all, arguments are much more fun when they‚Äôre written by James Goldman ‚Äî also behind the stellar ‚Äòolder people having feelings and also having swords‚Äô film, ‚ÄúRobin and Marian‚Äù ‚Äî and delivered with decades of built-up bombast by Catherine Hepburn and Peter O‚ÄôToole. The Anthony Harvey-directed movie finds the restless King Henry II (O‚ÄôToole) and the disgraced but still dangerous Eleanor of Aquitaine (Hepburn) thrown together for the Christmas season with their miserable failsons Richard (Anthony Hopkins), Geoffrey (John Castle), and John (Nigel Terry), who might be scheming against their dad. Everybody has feelings, betrayals, mad lusts for power, and a begrudging sense of connection, despite it all. ‚ÄúThe Lion In Winter‚Äù has some of the biggest showdowns and grandest dialogue of any movie you‚Äôll ever see, Christmas-themed or otherwise. In its largesse, it also has some of the most fun of any movie, Christmas-themed or otherwise. It‚Äôs well worth the trip to medieval times, where, as Eleanor sarcastically proclaims, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs 1183 and we‚Äôre barbarians!‚Äù ‚ÄîWC Appearing on IndieWire‚Äôs list of the best feminist horror movies ever made, this historic, final girl-defining slasher was directed by Bob Clark. Yes, that Bob Clark: the director behind the family favorite ‚ÄúA Christmas Story‚Äù among others. ‚ÄúBlack Christmas‚Äù and ‚ÄúA Christmas Story‚Äù are tonally disparate projects, to be sure. Still, you‚Äôll find a familiar glow akin to the Parker family‚Äôs Christmas tree lights framing plenty of frames in the the earlier horror flick: a warm halo around the suspense ‚Äì and carnage ‚Äî still to come. Set at a sorority house during the holidays, ‚ÄúBlack Christmas‚Äù stars Olivia Hussey as protagonist Jess. When menacing phone calls turn to bumps in the night and finally someone turns up dead, our heroine is forced to confront a killer lurking closer than she thinks. With a seriously vexing conclusion ‚Äî that‚Äôs effective but still maddening ‚Äî ‚ÄúBlack Christmas‚Äù is best saved for those willing to weather a yuletide nightmare only to come up with metaphoric coal come the ending. ‚ÄîAF ‚ÄúI made my family disappear.‚Äù In the role that turned a 10-year-old into a household name, Macaulay Culkin stars as ‚ÄúHome Alone‚Äù hero Kevin McAllister. Written and produced by John Hughes with Chris Columbus serving as director, this 1990 slapstick classic follows the MacGyver-esque Kevin after he‚Äôs accidentally left behind on his family‚Äôs Christmas vacation and forced to battle two home invaders back in his sleepy Chicago suburb. Jazzy Christmas carols and zippy one-liners (‚ÄúKeep the change, ya filthy animal!‚Äù) bind Culkin‚Äôs gleeful starring performance to Joe Pesci and Daniel Stern‚Äôs brilliant duo of burglars. But it‚Äôs Catherine O‚ÄôHara‚Äôs scenes, melting down as Kevin‚Äôs guilty and panicked mom Kate, that give the movie its enduring heart. ‚ÄúHome Alone‚Äù was followed up with a 1992 sequel set in New York City, once again starring Culkin, Pesci, Stern, and O‚ÄôHara. It‚Äôs a lesser movie, but still funny and well worth watching if you don‚Äôt already know what happens when Kevin spends a night at the Plaza. ‚ÄîAF Need a break from‚Ä¶everything? Let director Michael Curtiz‚Äôs 1954 Christmas spectacle transport you back in time with its old-world cool, polished performances, and gleefully bonkers musical logic. Princes of the silver screen Bing Crosby and Danny Kaye play friends Bob and Phil, who become singing and songwriting partners after nearly dying in World War II. (Like we said, musical logic!) When the men run across sisters Betty and Judy, played by Rosemary Clooney and Vera-Ellen, the four embark on a jazzy journey to the shockingly not-so-snowy Vermont. Say what you will of the Technicolor film‚Äôs story, but there‚Äôs no debating ‚ÄúWhite Christmas‚Äù contains masterful music. The namesake tune won Best Original Song in 1942 and is prolific enough that it‚Äôs likely playing in your head right now. But for this writer, there‚Äôs just no beating the imagery evoked in the lesser-known ‚ÄúSnow,‚Äù sung by the four stars aboard a train car. (‚ÄúIt won‚Äôt be long before we‚Äôll all be there with snow‚Ä¶.‚Äù ‚ÄúI want to wash my hands, my face and hair with snow‚Ä¶.‚Äù) ‚ÄîAF There‚Äôs an unabashed schmaltziness to writer/director Richard Curtis‚Äô ‚ÄúLove Actually‚Äù: a Christmas rom-com that‚Äôs at once intoxicatingly cheery in its sentimentality and sharply clever with its intricate design and British wit. Mainly set in London, with one subplot taking us to the French countryside and later Portugal, the 2003 title has become synonymous with a specific story structure. And though that moniker is sometimes doled out disparagingly (here‚Äôs looking at you, Garry Marshall‚Äôs ‚ÄúMother‚Äôs Day,‚Äù ‚ÄúValentine‚Äôs Day,‚Äù and ‚ÄúNew Year‚Äôs Eve‚Äù), there‚Äôs a reason so many tenderhearted movie lovers keep coming back to it. A star-studded cast ‚Äî Colin Firth, Chiwetel Ejiofor, Laura Linney, Billy Nighy, and the late Alan Rickman, among others ‚Äî charm their way through nine holiday tales tied together by character relationships and some iconic wrap-around narration from Hugh Grant, who plays a lovestruck prime minister. ‚ÄîAF Diane Keaton as the warm, thick-glasses-clad mom! Craig T. Nelson as the emotionally open and even-keeled dad! Luke Wilson as the stoner brother! Rachel McAdams as the tote-swinging, crunchy granola sister! Truly, there are very few fictional families that are more of a joy to spend Christmas with than the family Stone ‚Äî though Sarah Jessica Parker‚Äôs uptight girlfriend forced to spend Christmas with them thanks to her boyfriend, a golden boy son played by Dermot Mulroney, would probably disagree. ‚ÄúThe Family Stone‚Äù wasn‚Äôt a particularly well-received film upon release, but 20 years have made this Christmas comedy of errors a staple watch and a classic, and that‚Äôs all thanks to the incredible cast that manages the delicate balance between comedy and drama that Thomas Bezucha‚Äôs movie offers. McAdams is the standout, but everyone gets a moment to shine, and it‚Äôs really hard difficult to think of a better Christmas gift than vegging out to their antics for a second or third or 400th rewatch. ‚ÄîWC The Grinch may reign supreme as cinema‚Äôs most instantly recognizable Christmas scoundrel. But Billy Bob Thornton‚Äôs titular ‚ÄúBad Santa,‚Äù a conman named Willie T. Soke who once a year teams up with his partner Marcus Skidmore (Tony Cox) to steal from shopping malls in a dastardly Santa scam, easily ranks among the top five holiday movie hooligans. Directed by Terry Zwigoff, this 2003 dark comedy achieves the kind of naughty fun later films (think the aptly named ‚ÄúA Bad Moms Christmas‚Äù) would attempt, but with an earnest nastiness that heightens its humor to near-flying sleigh heights. As Willie‚Äôs myriad addictions and intense selfishness threaten the criminals‚Äô partnership ‚Äî against a backdrop of scheming from a cast that includes Lauren Tom and Bernie Mac, plus the much-celebrated performance of then 8-year-old Brett Kelly ‚Äî the explosively violent fallout forces the titular coal receiver to reconsider his life. ‚ÄúBad Santa‚Äù was eventually followed by 2016‚Äôs ‚ÄúBad Santa 2,‚Äù which offers some of the same fun but is significantly more clumsy than the first. ‚ÄîAF Unafraid to challenge the filmmakers who came before her, Greta Gerwig remade ‚ÄúLittle Women‚Äù in 2019: the triumphant sixth film adaptation of Louisa May Alcott‚Äôs well-loved tale of four sisters growing up in Massachusetts at the turn of the century. The Best Picture nominee reunited its writer/director with ‚ÄúLady Bird‚Äù star Saoirse Ronan as Jo alongside Emma Watson as Meg, Florence Pugh as Amy, and Eliza Scanlen as Beth. Laura Dern and Bob Odenkirk played the girls‚Äô parents with Timoth√©e Chalamet rounding out the cast as love interest Laurie. Oh, did we mention Meryl Streep? In the most literal sense, ‚ÄúLittle Women‚Äù is a Christmas film because it sets two pivotal scenes on the holiday. Alcott‚Äôs book famously opens with the girls grappling with a meager celebration on Christmas morning: an economic consequence of the American Civil War raging in the background. The second holiday in their story underlines the loss of one of the March sisters in a heartbreaking sequence that marks one of Gerwig‚Äôs most successful tragedies. But more than that, the film is brimming with love and sisterly affection as winter provides a fleeting backdrop to the heroines‚Äô individual weighing of sorrow, acceptance, spirit, and defiance. ‚ÄîAF Accept no substitutes. Reject all remakes. If you want the story of a tough as iron and sharp as nails career woman, living in the Big City‚Ñ¢ and forced, through a set of comedic circumstances, to pretend to be a farm wife for the holidays, look no further than 1945‚Äôs ‚ÄúChristmas In Connecticut.‚Äù The cast is lights-out incredible, anchored by Barbara Stanwyck as a woman‚Äôs advice columnist who‚Äôs never baked a pie, forced to return to her ‚Äúfamily home‚Äù in Connecticut to present some homemaking bona fides for her oblivious publisher and ably abetted by Dennis Morgan as a navy man (it is 1945) who Stanwyck bring in from the cold, if you know what I mean. But the supporting ensemble is an embarrassment of riches. You could power TCM for a week off of each of them: Sydney Greenstreet, S.Z. Sakall, Una O‚ÄôConnor, Reginald Gardiner. This movie is just fun, in that good old-fashioned way, sparking and charming and directed with a spritely touch by Peter Godfrey. Many other films run exactly the same playbook as ‚ÄúChristmas In Connecticut.‚Äù But there are very few who run it better. ‚ÄîSS ‚ÄúLast Holiday‚Äù wouldn‚Äôt stand out in the metaphoric rom-com Christmas tree lot without shining star Queen Latifah perched atop its scraggly story. When a terminally ill woman discovers her health insurance won‚Äôt cover the price of a necessary operation (seriously dark, but that‚Äôs American healthcare for you!), she decides to blow the last of her money on a solo vacation to the Czech Republic. With LL Cool J as her strapping love interest, Latifah‚Äôs Georgia breathes endless life into a wintery adventure that sees her new outlook seriously confusing hotel staff and guests. A case of mistaken identity (with an extra layer of irony, once you know the film‚Äôs ending) leads Georgia down a bow and holly-adorned adventure of fine dining, mud masks, snowboarding, and pissing off Timothy Hutton‚Äôs pompous antagonist that‚Äôs nothing if not fun. ‚ÄîAF National Lampoon‚Äôs Vacation franchise consists of four films starring Chevy Chase and Beverly D‚ÄôAngelo. (There‚Äôs five if you count the 2015 reboot with Ed Helms and Christina Applegate, and six if you count the straight-to-video spinoff ‚ÄúChristmas Vacation 2‚Äù: a Randy Quaid vehicle from 2003 that barely makes it out of the metaphoric parking lot.) While there are merits to each of these harebrained family trips/events ‚Äî particularly the original 1983 outing to Wally World directed by the late Harold Ramis ‚Äî few would deny that writer/producer John Hughes and director Jeremiah S. Chechik‚Äôs ‚ÄúChristmas Vacation‚Äù is a top-of-the-tree, crowning achievement for the series. Reprising their parts as Clark and Ellen Griswold, Chase and D‚ÄôAngelo are joined by the best ensemble cast the franchise ever saw with a sprawling family that‚Äôs only sometimes lovable but always believable. The 1985 comedy boasts supporting performances from then-kid actors Juliette Lewis and Johnny Galecki ‚Äî the best Griswold kids ever cast ‚Äî as well as Julia Louis-Dreyfus and Nicholas Guest as the Griswolds‚Äô memorably awful neighbors. (‚ÄúWhy is the carpet all wet, Todd?‚Äù ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know, Margo.‚Äù) ‚ÄîAF Before the (surprisingly demanding?) era of Airbnb, swapping homes for Christmas break provided a romantic premise for Nancy Meyers‚Äô ‚ÄúThe Holiday.‚Äù Kate Winslet and Cameron Diaz star as a Brit and an American ‚Äî both spinning in the wake of infidelity in their relationships ‚Äî who agree to stay in one another‚Äôs homes for the last two weeks of December. Once landed in Los Angeles and London respectively, the women run headlong into two aughts rom-com plots: prepared to their most satisfyingly saccharine. Jude Law plays opposite Diaz as a handsome book editor reeling from the loss of his late wife and struggling to cope with single parenthood. Back in the States, Jack Black charms Winslet as a movie score composer whose affable charisma would make him an obvious love interest, if he wasn‚Äôt already taken. Like a crushed-down ‚ÄúLove Actually,‚Äù ‚ÄúThe Holiday‚Äù hits familiar beats but keeps the story fresh with its four-hander structure. ‚ÄîAF Tom Burton‚Äôs weirder, freakier ‚ÄúBatman‚Äù sequel sets a strange psychosexual tale during Gothem‚Äôs holiday season, with Christmas ornaments and snow-covered skyscrapers making for a cheery backdrop to Bruce Wayne‚Äôs (Michael Keaton) melancholic battle against the villainous Penguin (Danny DeVito). As the vengeful ghoul runs for mayor and hatches a plan to kidnap the children of Gotham‚Äôs elite in a twisted Santa Claus plot, Bruce tangos with Catwoman Selina Kyle (Michelle Pfeiffer) both in and out of their spandex. Their chemistry makes for maybe the sexiest Christmas movie ever made, particularly when Pfeiffer seductively delivers the oh-so cheesy but oh-so-perfect line, ‚ÄúMistletoe can be deadly if you eat it. But a kiss can be even deadlier if you mean it.‚Äù ‚ÄîWC Set in the winter of 1970 and shot to look as if it had actually been made back then, Alexander Payne‚Äôs nuanced and hyper-literate ‚ÄúThe Holdovers‚Äù takes great pleasure in defying every impulse of modern cinema from even before the moment it starts (the studio fanfare includes a ‚Äúthrowback‚Äù Focus Features logo, which is a cute little in-joke about a company that wasn‚Äôt founded until 2002). And yet, it might take even greater pleasure in embracing some of the movies‚Äô most time-honored tropes and traditions. Chief among them: The inviolable rule that anything a school teacher ‚Äúcasually‚Äù tells their students in the first act of a film must speak to a core idea of the film itself. In that light, be sure to take notes during the opening scene in which Paul Hunham (Paul Giamatti) quotes Cicero to the ‚Äúvulgar philistines‚Äù in his Ancient Civilization class. ‚ÄúNon nobis solum nati sumus.‚Äù ‚ÄúNot for ourselves alone are we born.‚Äù No spoilers, but that‚Äôs definitely going to be on the final exam of ‚ÄúThe Holdovers,‚Äù which gradually thaws into a slight but sensitive tale about a trio of lonely souls who teach each other to push through their lives‚Äô most isolating disappointments. ‚ÄîDE Let‚Äôs be real: ‚ÄúGremlins 2‚Äù is significantly more fun than its 1984 predecessor. If you don‚Äôt already know that in your bones, then you should prioritize seeing the nonseasonal sequel ‚Äî and possibly its spot-on ‚ÄúKey & Peele‚Äù parody ‚Äî first. That said, ‚ÄúGremlins‚Äù is the holiday half of Joe Dante‚Äôs creature duology, and it has more than enough zip to satisfy fans of ‚Äô80s camp looking for a quintessential horror holiday. When a traveling salesman (the late Hoyt Axton) brings home a strange new pet for his son, known as a ‚Äúmogwai,‚Äù hero Billy Peltzer (Zach Gilligan) is tasked with abiding by three rules of care: no sunlight, no water, and no feeding it after midnight. Naturally, it takes no time at all for Billy to screw up and unleash the consequences of his adorable Christmas present on his unsuspecting town. ‚ÄúGremlins‚Äù qualifies as top holiday viewing not only because its zany antics take place at Christmas, but because it also includes one of the most baffling beats in ‚ÄúHome Alone‚Äù director Chris Columbus‚Äô screenwriting history. Truly, Phoebe Cates‚Äô infamous Santa-in-a-chimney monologue is one tonal mystery that keeps on giving. ‚ÄîAF What do NYPD detective John McClane and classic holiday singer Bing Crosby have in common? They‚Äôll both be home for Christmas. John McTiernan‚Äôs ‚ÄúDie Hard‚Äù chronicles the ill-fated reunion of Bruce Willis‚Äô starring action hero and his estranged wife Holly (Bonnie Bedelia) at her company‚Äôs Christmas party in Los Angeles. McClane‚Äôs plans to win his wife back come undone when a high-stakes heist disguised as a terrorist attack takes over the festivities thanks to Alan Rickman‚Äôs notorious villain Hans Gruber. At its core, ‚ÄúDie Hard‚Äù is a tale of redemption. Sure, he‚Äôs not as on-the-nose naughty as the Grinch or Scrooge, but McClane is paying for past mistakes through the hellish ordeal that unfolds before/beneath/beside/above him in an explosive act of absolution. Even more memorable is the story of Al Powell (Reginald VelJohnson), an LAPD officer whose history on the force motivates the film‚Äôs heroic climax. If that worthy Christmas message isn‚Äôt reason enough for you to check it out, then trust that the script is full of holiday gems: from saccharine platitudes (‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Christmas, Theo! It‚Äôs the time of miracles‚Ä¶‚Äù) to season‚Äôs greetings (‚ÄúYippee-ki-yay, motherfuckers!‚Äù) ‚ÄîAF Bob Clark‚Äôs ‚ÄúA Christmas Story‚Äù has a rhythmic familiarity for some families: celebrated each year in an all-day marathon on TBS, seamlessly looping from Ralphie‚Äôs initial request for a Red Ryder carbine-action BB gun (that‚Äôs the ‚Äú200-shot, range model air rifle with a compass in the stock and this thing that tells time,‚Äù of course) to the warm glow of Christmas morning when he discovers whether or not his dream present made it in under the tree. Along the way, Jean Shepherd, who co-wrote the script with Clark and Leigh Brown (not to mention narrates as an older Ralphie), imbues the Parker family with details from his real life, first appearing in his short stories. The road-weary marriage of Melinda Dillon and Darren McGavin‚Äôs Mrs. and Mr. Parker stands out as a testament to parents pushing to their absolute limits to make Christmas miracles. ‚ÄîAF Not to be confused with its 1994 remake (though the Mara Wilson vehicle does have its moments), 1947‚Äôs ‚ÄúMiracle on 34th Street‚Äù is the masterwork of writer/director George Seaton that continues to shape how New Yorkers honor the holidays. The black-and-white film stars Edmund Gwenn as Kris Kringle: the new Santa at a Macy‚Äôs department store who shocks the city when he claims to be the real Saint Nick. An 8-year-old Natalie Wood plays Susan: a little girl whose faith in Kringle becomes central to the fairytale‚Äôs message. ‚ÄúMiracle on 34th Street‚Äù was nominated in multiple categories at that year‚Äôs Oscars, including Best Picture. It won three: two for writing and one for Gwenn, who clinched Best Supporting Actor. ‚ÄîAF There are two film adaptations of Charles Dickens‚Äô ‚ÄúA Christmas Carol‚Äù appearing on this list, with many, many more available. And though Brian Henson‚Äôs 1992 family favorite ranks lower than its competition, we can confidently say it‚Äôs got the better puppets. With Kermit the Frog (performed by Steve Whitmire) as its Bob Cratchit and Michael Caine playing Ebenezer Scrooge, ‚ÄúThe Muppet Christmas Carol‚Äù stays remarkably close to its Gothic source material: a smart grounding move that heightens the film‚Äôs bursts of Muppet parody to among the funniest in the ongoing franchise. Come for the promise of punny characters (Fozziewig!) and catchy musical numbers (‚ÄúIt feels like Chriiistmaaas!‚Äù). Stay for the goofy witticisms only the Muppets can do justice: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a little absent-minded, spirit.‚Äù ‚ÄúNo, I‚Äôm a large absent-minded spirit!‚Äù ‚ÄîAF The holidays are a time of joy, but they‚Äôre also bittersweet. ‚ÄúThe Apartment‚Äù is one of the great melancholy Christmas films, a movie about being lonely and blue during that confusing period between Christmas and New Year‚Äôs. Jack Lemmon stars as meek office drone Baxter, who uses his bachelor pad to get ahead in his career by loaning it out as an affair spot for his married superiors. But when his office crush, elevator operator Fran (Shirley MacLaine, luminous), engages in an affair with the head of the company, he‚Äôs forced to reconsider the morals of what he‚Äôs doing, and what he really wants out of his life. It‚Äôs not the most cheery Christmas film of all time, but its perfectly awkward office holiday party scene and running joke about sending a fruitcake to a person whose heart you broke every December 25 firmly establish it in the sad Christmas canon. ‚ÄîWC The swan song of legendary Swedish auteur Ingmar Bergman, ‚ÄúFanny and Alexander‚Äù is an epic in miniature, capturing the lives of two young children born to a wealthy family as they contend with death and abuse but find comfort in themselves and their large extended family. The film, which in its uncut form runs over five hours long, begins with an extended act showcasing the decadent celebrations of the Ekdahl family across Christmas ‚Äî a relatively secular tradition in which even the Jewish uncle Isak is allowed to partake. The warmth and joy on display (it‚Äôs one of the most gorgeous Christmas parties in film history) make the rest of the film ‚Äî where the siblings‚Äô father dies, and their mother remarries to a severe and abusive Protestant bishop ‚Äî all the more stark in their cold isolation. Through the contrast between these two methods of religious celebration, ‚ÄúFanny and Alexander‚Äù is one of the few Christmas films to seriously contend with the religion of Christianity itself, asking questions about the role spirituality plays in our lives, and whether it can lead one to happiness or ruin. ‚ÄîWC Its sunny yellow Miami lighting doesn‚Äôt scream Christmas. But ‚ÄúTangerine,‚Äù Sean Baker‚Äôs breakout film, is very much of the season, taking place entirely on Christmas Eve. The madcap dramedy stars Kitana Kiki Rodriguez as Sin-Dee, a sex worker released from a short jail stint who discovers her boyfriend has been cheating on her. Enraged, she recruits her fellow prostitute and friend Alexandra (Mya Taylor) to help her find him. The film largely focuses on the two engaging in some very non-Christmas activities, from screaming fights to smoking meth. But their sweet friendship and almost sisterly bond keep the film of the season: if the holidays are about family, then the found family relationship seen in ‚ÄúTangerine‚Äù is one of the best. ‚ÄîWC Satoshi Kon is best known for his mind-bending, meta films like ‚ÄúPaprika‚Äù or ‚ÄúPerfect Blue,‚Äù movies that toy with ideas of self-perception, delusion, and identity. But between those enigmatic releases, he dropped ‚ÄúTokyo Godfathers,‚Äù a bittersweet tragicomedy Christmas film rooted in the down-and-out lives of ordinary people in modern-day Japan. The result is still one of the most offbeat and unusual Christmas films ever made, and also one of the most heartwarming. Heavily inspired by John Ford‚Äôs 1948 Western ‚Äú3 Godfathers,‚Äù ‚ÄúTokyo Godfathers‚Äù moves that story of gunslingers attempting to shepherd a baby to safety to Tokyo, where our heroes are three homeless people who find an abandoned child in the trash on Christmas Eve. Their journey across the city to find the kid‚Äôs parents is difficult and alternates between hilarious and sobering, but there‚Äôs an affection for these unlikely heroes that shines through the jokes. It‚Äôs a lovely look at the unluckiest of people during the season of giving. ‚ÄîWC For even some readers who first encountered the ghostly tale of Ebeneezer Scrooge on the page, the late Scottish actor Alastair Sim is the face of literature‚Äôs most famed redemptive protagonist. Directed by Brian Desmond Hurst, this 1951 black-and-white adaptation of ‚ÄúA Christmas Carol‚Äù ‚Äî also known as ‚ÄúScrooge‚Äù ‚Äî enjoys an otherworldly quality emanating from its now-antiquated filmmaking and Dickens‚Äô illustrious prose: exploring the supernatural side to Christmas in a winding story of a greedy businessman confronting his misdeeds via poltergeist. Sim‚Äôs turn as Scrooge sees the seasoned actor dexterously scale the philosophical work‚Äôs Jacob‚Äôs ladder, guiding the unlikely hero from a horror-esque villain to a soft-smiled man making peace with his life. He‚Äôd lead Guy Hamilton‚Äôs ‚ÄúAn Inspector Calls‚Äù as the titular inspector calling just two years later, in 1954. ‚ÄîAF Will Ferrell brings the Christmas spirit and then some in Jon Favreau‚Äôs fish-out-of-water (elf-out-of-snow?) 2003 comedy about an effervescent Christmas enthusiast visiting gritty New York City. After spending his entire life with Santa in the North Pole, Buddy the Elf arrives in Manhattan like a breath of syrup/candy/spaghetti-infused air: challenging his nasty Scrooge of an estranged father (the late James Caan) to accept his seemingly boundless love and affection. From picking out an ill-conceived gift for that ‚Äúspecial someone‚Äù to cutting down a tree in Central Park (a serious and illegal whoopsie!), ‚ÄúElf‚Äù is chockfull of familiar traditions twisted to their most misguided and extreme. It‚Äôs a crowdpleaser not just for fans of Ferrell and kids who grew up in the aughts, but anyone needing a reason to enjoy the season. After all, say it with me: ‚ÄúThe best way to spread Christmas cheer is singing loud for all to hear.‚Äù ‚ÄîAF ‚ÄúHave Yourself a Merry Little Christmas‚Äù is often used and recorded as a light, jubilant, or romantic song. But the iconic standard, as introduced by a sprightly Judy Garland in ‚ÄúMeet Me in St. Louis,‚Äù is actually a massive downer, a desperate attempt at comfort and happiness during a loved one‚Äôs darkest hour. Garland, whose rich voice has never been more beautiful, performs the song in the technicolor Vincente Minnelli musical as hopeless romantic Esther to her little sister Tootie (Margaret O‚ÄôBrien) after they discover their father will be moving the whole family away from their home. It‚Äôs meant to comfort Tootie, but also herself, as she will be ripped away from the boy she loves right after he proposed to her. The scene on Christmas Eve is the only part of ‚ÄúMeet Me in St. Louis‚Äù that actually focuses on the holidays, but its perfect blend of melancholy and beauty makes the film an essential entry in the Christmas canon. ‚ÄîWC Cate Blanchett and Rooney Mara will knock the breath from your chest in Todd Haynes‚Äô ‚ÄúCarol.‚Äù Adapted for the screen by Phyllis Nagy, from Patricia Highsmith‚Äôs 1952 ‚ÄúThe Price of Salt,‚Äù this lesbian period romance (a subgenre done to death, we know) chronicles the swelling attraction between the shop girl/aspiring photographer Therese Belivet and the magnetic soon-to-be divorcee Carol Aird. At first blush, one might clump the women‚Äôs love story ‚Äî featuring clandestine looks framed in artificial snow and an understated meet-cute involving a Santa hat ‚Äî with other seasonal romances, such as ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve Got Mail‚Äù or ‚ÄúLove Actually‚Äù (also appearing on this list). But where those romantic comedies cut their lovers‚Äô budding tension with holiday antics, ‚ÄúCarol‚Äù dares to stare deep into the melancholy thoughtfulness that comes with this time of year by incorporating a heart-rending story of a gay woman fighting to be with her daughter. The result gifts romance fans a slow-burn consideration of the bold futures we choose to allow ourselves and a final shot that will make your heart grow three sizes. ‚ÄîAF It‚Äôd be a little cliched to crown director Frank Capra‚Äôs ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a Wonderful Life‚Äù the best Christmas movie of all time: what with the seemingly endless references and homages to it appearing in other holiday films. And yet, to deny hero George Bailey‚Äôs all-time heartbreaker one of the top spots feels just about as nice list-qualifying as denying Santa his cookies. Plus, who really needs to justify giving a James Stewart performance ‚Äî arguably, his best (though the legendary actor would only win an Oscar for 1940‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Philadelphia Story‚Äù) ‚Äî supreme accolades? Based on Philip Van Doren Stern‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Greatest Gift,‚Äù this 1946 black-and-white fable considers the melancholia and existential despair characteristic for so many at the holidays. When news of a man‚Äôs suicidal thoughts reach heaven, Henry Travers‚Äô guardian angel character Clarence Odbody intervenes. For those with a heavy heart this time of year ‚Äî or any for that matter ‚Äî ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a Wonderful Life‚Äù offers a hopeful salve from an old world. ‚ÄîAF It takes a special kind of balding, depressed, zig-zag-wearing kid to anchor not one, not two, but three major holiday specials. Four if you count ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the Great Pumpkin, Charlie Brown,‚Äù ‚ÄúA Charlie Brown Thanksgiving,‚Äù ‚ÄúA Charlie Brown Christmas,‚Äù and ‚ÄúA Charlie Brown Valentine‚Äù (though that last one might be on the fringes of modern popularity and there are other lesser titles we‚Äôre not mentioning). After Lucy asks Charlie Brown to direct the Christmas play, he‚Äôs thrust into a challenging leadership position that sees him battling Schroeder‚Äôs piano and the rest of the gang‚Äôs antics for attention. Simultaneously, Linus considers the biblical origins of the holiday and ponders what we owe to one another. The best friends‚Äô journeys meet at night in a cold lot, where Charlie Brown picks out what may very well be the most instantly recognizable Christmas tree in TV and film history. ‚ÄîAF Stanley Kubrick‚Äôs final movie is unlike any other of the holly-jolly titles on this list, but there‚Äôs no denying the late filmmaker had something to say about Christmas with his sordid tale of a husband and wife‚Äôs thorny encounter with an underground sex cult. Finished just days before Kubrick‚Äôs death, ‚ÄúEyes Wide Shut‚Äù stars Nicole Kidman and Tom Cruise as a raw nerve of a couple whose growing resentment culminates in a would-be affair spun out of control. Tinsel and lights offer an obvious (and ominously gorgeous) seasonal background for the film, released in July 1999. But it‚Äôs Kubrick‚Äôs repeated presentation of the holiday‚Äôs innate consumerism that drives home his thesis ‚Äî or at least one interpretation of a thesis! ‚Äî that marriages and families can be hungrily consumed by the vapid mundanity of self-obsession and competitive capitalism. ‚ÄîAF Not just one of the greatest Christmas rom-coms, but one of the greatest rom-coms period, ‚ÄúThe Shop Around the Corner‚Äù and its tale of pen pals falling in love during the Christmas season has been adapted and modernized several times, such as in the Broadway musical ‚ÄúShe Loves Me‚Äù or ‚Äô90s email film ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve Got Mail.‚Äù But Ernst Lubitsch‚Äôs original, based on the play ‚ÄúParfumerie,‚Äù remains the greatest telling. In the Budapest leathergoods shop where they work, Klara (Margaret Sullavan) and Alfred (James Stewart) bicker endlessly, but in the anonymous letters they write to each other, they both reveal their softer sides and find themselves smitten with the stranger they don‚Äôt know. Both actors are phenomenal, with beautiful simple chemistry that‚Äôs alternatively spiky and sweet. They‚Äôre supported by a lovely cast, including Frank Morgan as the owner of the store Matuschek who discovers his wife is having an affair. What makes the film such a holiday great is its exploration of lonlieness during the winter months, from the two leads struggling to find love to Matuschek‚Äôs despair over his situation. It‚Äôs a simple but moving story about finding connection, and how love and companionship can be the greatest gift of all. ‚ÄîWC By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy. We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

Title: AST SpaceMobile Aims to Launch FM2, Its Second Prototype Satellite, in January
URL: https://uk.pcmag.com/wireless-carriers/161905/ast-spacemobile-aims-to-launch-fm2-its-second-prototype-satellite-in-january
Time Published: 2025-12-08T15:51:40Z
Full Content:
PCMag editors select and review products independently. If you buy through affiliate links, we may earn commissions, which help support our testing. Our team tests, rates, and reviews more than 1,500 products each year to help you make better buying decisions and get more from technology. AST SpaceMobile is hoping to launch a second next-generation prototype satellite "as early as January" as it races to compete with SpaceX‚Äôs cellular Starlink service. The company disclosed the launch timing in a new Federal Communications Commission filing. AST is already on track to launch its first prototype satellite, FM1, later this month. However, it appears that it's also scrambling to launch the FM2 as soon as possible. ‚ÄúAs part of its proactive efforts to secure sufficient launches for its satellite constellation on an expedited basis, AST SpaceMobile was able to secure an accelerated launch slot capable of launching a BlueBird satellite as early as January 2026,‚Äù the company wrote. Interestingly, AST has tapped rival SpaceX to launch the satellite using a Falcon 9 rocket. But the filing notes: ‚ÄúIn order to meet quick turnaround launch requirements, AST SpaceMobile was constrained in the available orbital parameters for launch. The alternative was to forgo the launch opportunity.‚Äù The company secured FCC clearance in August to fly up the FM2. However, the "constrained" orbit parameters are leading AST to request regulatory permission to launch the FM2 satellite at a lower orbit, from 520 kilometers down to 460 kilometers. AST describes the lower orbit as part of ‚Äúa few minor changes‚Äù that won‚Äôt lead to increased radio interference. ‚ÄúGrant of this application will serve the public interest by facilitating expeditious deployment of a new, groundbreaking space-based cellular network that will deliver direct-to-device broadband connectivity across the United States,‚Äù the company added. Still, the company‚Äôs application might face opposition from rival companies, such as SpaceX. It could also take time for the FCC to review and clear the application, although the Commission has been working to fast-track satellite approvals. AST‚Äôs first prototype, the FM1, is currently scheduled to launch on Dec. 15. The company has tapped India‚Äôs space agency to launch the satellite, which is about three times larger than AST's first-generation BlueBirds. The square-shaped satellites have been designed to act as cell towers in space, capable of powering high-speed broadband to phones on the ground. The goal is to operate 45 to 60 BlueBird satellites by the end of next year‚Äîenough for the company to provide continuous coverage through partners such as AT&T and Verizon. In addition, ‚ÄúAST SpaceMobile expects five orbital launches by the end of Q1 2026, with launches occurring every one to two months on average,‚Äù the company told the FCC. Hence, the launch timing is crucial when AST faces heightened competition from SpaceX. The company's own cellular Starlink system launched through T-Mobile earlier this year, and can already power text messaging, app data, and even video calls for phones in cellular dead zones. Now SpaceX is preparing to bulk up the system‚Äôs capabilities after acquiring valuable radio spectrum from Boost Mobile‚Äôs parent, EchoStar. Elon Musk's company has even gone as far as to file the trademark for ‚ÄúStarlink Mobile,‚Äù suggesting SpaceX might try to become a global carrier, but primarily through satellites. My ExperienceI've been a journalist for over 15 years. I got my start as a schools and cities reporter in Kansas City and joined PCMag in 2017, where I cover satellite internet services, cybersecurity, PC hardware, and more. I'm currently based in San Francisco, but previously spent over five years in China, covering the country's technology sector.Since 2020, I've covered the launch and explosive growth of SpaceX's Starlink satellite internet service, writing 600+ stories on availability and feature launches, but also the regulatory battles over the expansion of satellite constellations, fights with rival providers like AST SpaceMobile and Amazon, and the effort to expand into satellite-based mobile service. I've combed through FCC filings for the latest news and driven to remote corners of California to test Starlink's cellular service. I also cover cyber threats, from ransomware gangs to the emergence of AI-based malware. Earlier this year, the FTC forced Avast to pay consumers $16.5 million for secretly harvesting and selling their personal information to third-party clients, as revealed in my joint investigation with Motherboard.I also cover the PC graphics card market. Pandemic-era shortages led me to camp out in front of a Best Buy to get an RTX 3000. I'm now following how President Trump's tariffs will affect the industry. I'm always eager to learn more, so please jump in the comments with feedback and send me tips.The Best Tech I've Had:My first video game console: a Nintendo FamicomI loved my Sega Saturn despite PlayStation's popularity.The iPod Video I received as a gift in collegeXbox 360 FTWThe Galaxy Nexus was the first smartphone I was proud to own.The PC desktop I built in 2013, which still works to this day. I've been a journalist for over 15 years. Title: AST SpaceMobile Aims to Launch FM2, Its Second Prototype Satellite, in January
URL: https://me.pcmag.com/en/old-wireless-carriers/34015/ast-spacemobile-aims-to-launch-fm2-its-second-prototype-satellite-in-january
Time Published: 2025-12-08T15:51:40Z
Full Content:
Our team tests, rates, and reviews more than 1,500 products each year to help you make better buying decisions and get more from technology. My ExperienceI've been a journalist for over 15 years. I got my start as a schools and cities reporter in Kansas City and joined PCMag in 2017, where I cover satellite internet services, cybersecurity, PC hardware, and more. I'm currently based in San Francisco, but previously spent over five years in China, covering the country's technology sector.Since 2020, I've covered the launch and explosive growth of SpaceX's Starlink satellite internet service, writing 600+ stories on availability and feature launches, but also the regulatory battles over the expansion of satellite constellations, fights with rival providers like AST SpaceMobile and Amazon, and the effort to expand into satellite-based mobile service. I've combed through FCC filings for the latest news and driven to remote corners of California to test Starlink's cellular service. I also cover cyber threats, from ransomware gangs to the emergence of AI-based malware. Earlier this year, the FTC forced Avast to pay consumers $16.5 million for secretly harvesting and selling their personal information to third-party clients, as revealed in my joint investigation with Motherboard.I also cover the PC graphics card market. Pandemic-era shortages led me to camp out in front of a Best Buy to get an RTX 3000. I'm now following how President Trump's tariffs will affect the industry. I'm always eager to learn more, so please jump in the comments with feedback and send me tips.The Best Tech I've Had:My first video game console: a Nintendo FamicomI loved my Sega Saturn despite PlayStation's popularity.The iPod Video I received as a gift in collegeXbox 360 FTWThe Galaxy Nexus was the first smartphone I was proud to own.The PC desktop I built in 2013, which still works to this day. I've been a journalist for over 15 years. I got my start as a schools and cities reporter in Kansas City and joined PCMag in 2017, where I cover satellite internet services, cybersecurity, PC hardware, and more. I'm currently based in San Francisco, but previously spent over five years in China, covering the country's technology sector. Since 2020, I've covered the launch and explosive growth of SpaceX's Starlink satellite internet service, writing 600+ stories on availability and feature launches, but also the regulatory battles over the expansion of satellite constellations, fights with rival providers like AST SpaceMobile and Amazon, and the effort to expand into satellite-based mobile service. I've combed through FCC filings for the latest news and driven to remote corners of California to test Starlink's cellular service. I also cover cyber threats, from ransomware gangs to the emergence of AI-based malware. Earlier this year, the FTC forced Avast to pay consumers $16.5 million for secretly harvesting and selling their personal information to third-party clients, as revealed in my joint investigation with Motherboard. I also cover the PC graphics card market. Pandemic-era shortages led me to camp out in front of a Best Buy to get an RTX 3000. I'm now following how President Trump's tariffs will affect the industry. I'm always eager to learn more, so please jump in the comments with feedback and send me tips. Title: Yep, Xbox Is Bleeding Out
URL: https://gizmodo.com/xbox-is-bleeding-out-black-friday-2025-sales-2000696718
Time Published: 2025-12-08T15:33:20Z
Full Content:
All products featured here are independently selected by our editors and writers. If you buy something through links on our site, Gizmodo may earn an affiliate commission. Reading time 3 minutes Like the worst sort of father, Xbox doesn√¢¬Ä¬ôt show much care for its youngest consoles anymore, at least judging solely by recent sales data. Black Friday weekend, normally one of the most important for any brand for pre-holiday sales, shows Xbox got beat out by Nintendo, Sony, and√¢¬Ä¬îto give the news an ounce of irony√¢¬Ä¬îeven a relatively obscure Kinect-like console. Mat Piscatella, a video game industry analyst at Circana, reported that the PlayStation 5 accounted for 47% of total Black Friday week console sales, in the U.S. ending Nov. 29. That makes sense, considering the console was on sale for about 40% at some retailers. Sony‚Äôs console√¢¬Ä¬îboth the digital version and one with a disc drive√¢¬Ä¬îwas on sale for less than even its pre-hike price. Meanwhile, coming up second was the Nintendo Switch 2 at 24% of total sales. The second-generation handheld console was on sale for $50 off the normally $500 Mario Kart World bundle from Walmart and Amazon. Finally, coming in third was the NEX Playground at 14%. See Xbox Series X and S at Amazon In the US, PlayStation 5 accounted for 47% of total Black Friday week hardware unit sales, leading the market. Nintendo Switch 2 ranked 2nd (24%), with the NEX Playground 3rd (14%). Source: Circana Retail Tracking Service [image or embed] √¢¬Ä¬î Mat Piscatella (@matpiscatella.bsky.social) December 6, 2025 at 3:37 PM What√¢¬Ä¬ôs the NEX Playground, you may ask? It√¢¬Ä¬ôs an Android-based platform made for younger children. It includes motion sensors that can read body movements for games such as Fruit Ninja or tie-in titles like How to Train Your Dragon: Riders of the Skies. Yes, that‚Äôs very much like the long-defunct Kinect. It√¢¬Ä¬ôs a very specific kind of console that may make sense for budget-conscious families. What√¢¬Ä¬ôs missing from this pie chart is the Xbox Series S and Series X. Microsoft pushed no sales for its consoles during Black Friday week. Even if some retailers went out of their way to move stock with extra gift cards or game sales, Xbox itself wasn√¢¬Ä¬ôt helping push the needle. The current Xbox Series X costs $650 after this year√¢¬Ä¬ôs latest price hike. The same console cost $500 at launch in 2020. Piscatella wrote on Bluesky, √¢¬Ä¬úStuff that does not price promote (generally speaking, here) does not see much of a seasonal lift at all from the prior week (usually none).√¢¬Ä¬ù Since the PS5 was the most heavily discounted, it received the lion√¢¬Ä¬ôs share of additional sales. Xbox either did not think it was necessary to push sales, or the brand just doesn√¢¬Ä¬ôt care anymore. Xbox√¢¬Ä¬ôs whole strategy is now focused on software. If it does finally release a next-gen Xbox, it will likely be a premium, expensive gaming device made for players who want the very best. That means the Xbox Series consoles don√¢¬Ä¬ôt really have a place anymore. There have been signs that Xbox has been shipping far fewer consoles to retailers, such that Costco removed the company√¢¬Ä¬ôs consoles from its U.S. and UK websites. The move toward a software-based gaming ecosystem is inevitably disappointing for Xbox fans. At the same time, the cost of RAM and SSD memory blew past the point of reason several weeks ago, and it keeps getting worse. Burgeoning AI data centers are willing to pay so much for memory that semiconductor companies have created a drought of consumer-ready DRAM (dynamic random access memory). The reliable leaker Moore√¢¬Ä¬ôs Law is Dead reported Sony stockpiled enough memory for the short term, but the RAM shortage could last through 2028. Yes, RAM prices could still be out of control a few years from now. Meanwhile, Xbox√¢¬Ä¬ôs cloud gaming service has reportedly seen an uptick in total usage hours lately. Whether that means there are more people buying into Game Pass is another question entirely. Microsoft hasn√¢¬Ä¬ôt been willing to share total subscriber numbers recently. There√¢¬Ä¬ôs a chance Microsoft√¢¬Ä¬ôs strategy will win out over the traditionalists like Sony and Nintendo. But for now, its console business is bleeding out so fast, it likely won√¢¬Ä¬ôt last long. And things aren‚Äôt going to get easier for Xbox. Valve is launching its Steam Machine in early 2026 and there will no doubt be all kinds of third-party console-sized PCs of the same ilk.√Ç When the next-gen Xbox does arrive, it won‚Äôt be a battle directly with Sony‚Äôs ‚ÄúPS6.‚Äù The console wars will have changed by then, with more players fighting for the living room than ever before. See Xbox Series X and S at Amazon Explore more on these topics Share this story Subscribe and interact with our community, get up to date with our customised Newsletters and much more. Gadgets gifts are the best gifts to get friends and family. The Analogue 3D now comes in all the transparent colorways you never got as a kid. Samsung's 40-inch, curved gaming monitor will fit the needs of those who prefer to play in a dark, dank place. And it√¢¬Ä¬ôs making us even more excited for the rumored PlayStation 6 handheld. With prices for PC parts skyrocketing, maybe streaming your games isn't so bad... if you can stomach the subscription. So-called 'Foot keyboards' are cursed in more ways than one. √Ç¬©2025 GIZMODO USA LLC. All rights reserved.

Title: Invesco Teams Up With LGT on Private Equity and Credit for Retail
URL: https://www.wealthmanagement.com/alternative-investments/invesco-teams-up-with-lgt-on-private-equity-and-credit-for-retail
Time Published: 2025-12-08T15:19:35Z
Full Content:
It‚Äôs at least the second partnership Invesco has struck since late April, when it joined with Barings on private credit funds. December 8, 2025 (Bloomberg) --Invesco Ltd. is taking another step to expand its presence in private markets, teaming up with LGT Capital Partners on portfolios of alternative assets for US retail and retirement investors. The plan will cover private equity, credit and infrastructure assets as well investments in the market for secondary stakes, the firms said Monday in a statement. It‚Äôs at least the second partnership Invesco has struck since late April, when the Atlanta-based firm that manages $2.1 trillion of client assets joined with Barings on private credit funds. ‚ÄúPrivate markets exposure can provide differentiated sources of income and growth,‚Äù Invesco Chief Executive Officer Andrew Schlossberg said in the statement. Read More: Invesco, Barings to Offer Private Credit to Everyday Clients Traditional managers of stocks and bonds have moved aggressively into alternative markets during the past year, buying boutique firms or striking joint ventures to sell private assets to everyday investors. Blackstone Inc. is teaming up with Vanguard Group and Wellington Management Co., Apollo Global Management Inc. partnered with State Street Corp., and Capital Group is working with KKR & Co. Meanwhile, BlackRock Inc. spent about $25 billion to acquire Global Infrastructure Partners and HPS Investment Partners. Related:RIA Edge Private Markets: Crosscurrents in Private Credit, Real Estate Invesco, best known for its QQQ equity funds tracking Nasdaq stocks, has more than $190 billion of alternative assets largely in real estate and private debt. It‚Äôs also a major manager of stable value funds common in retirement accounts, a type of product that could wind up allocating to private credit. LGT, with about $120 billion of assets, is owned by the Princely Family of Liechtenstein. ‚ÄúThe alliance marks a significant step in strengthening our presence in the US market, expanding our wealth management capabilities, and exploring opportunities in the retirement space,‚Äù Roberto Paganoni, LGT‚Äôs CEO, said in the statement. Silla Brush You May Also Like Trusts & Estates for Advisors Copyright ¬© 2025 Informa Connect Limited. Registered in England & Wales with number 01835199, registered office 5 Howick Place, London, SW1P 1WG.
